intro: Cecropia flagellifera, commonly known as the whipsnap tree, is a fast-growing tree native to tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the Moraceae family and is characterized by its large, palmate leaves and distinctive, pendulous inflorescences. The plant is known for its ability to form symbiotic relationships with ants, which provide protection in exchange for shelter and food. Its hollow stems are often used as nesting sites by birds and other animals. Cecropia flagellifera plays an important ecological role in its native habitats, contributing to biodiversity and forest structure.
